page.title: 7.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will work with problems that show patterns of change and be able to describe the patterns in mathematical terms. A new term, quadratic, will be used to describe patterns with squared terms.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe how a pattern is growing.
  • Tell whether a pattern is growing linearly, exponentially, or quadratically.
  • Explain that an expression with a squared term is called quadratic.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.2.1: Squares in a Geometric Pattern
  • 7.2.2: Constant and Exponential Change
    • 7.2.2: Self Check
    • 7.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.2.3: Quadratic Expressions
    • 7.2.3: Self Check
    • 7.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.2.4: Quadratic Relationships

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.2.5: Practice
  • 7.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.2.1: Squares in a Geometric Pattern
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

How does each expression represent the number of small squares in the figure?


  1. Expression A: \(6 \cdot 8−2 \cdot 3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There are 6 rows with 8 small squares, but from this, 2 rows of 3 small squares have been removed.



  1. Expression B: \(4 \cdot 8+2 \cdot 5\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There are 4 rows of 8 small squares, and to this, 2 rows of 5 small squares are added.



  1. Expression C: \(8+8+8+8+5+5\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This counts each row, starting from the bottom.



  1. Expression D: \(5 \cdot 6+3 \cdot 4\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There are 5 columns of 6 small squares and 3 columns of 4 small squares.

page.title: 7.2.2: Constant and Exponential Change
page.contents:
Activity

Pattern 1

Pattern 2


  1. Look at Pattern 1.
    1. How is the number of dots in each step changing?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Each step has 2 rows of dots, with each row having the same number of dots as the step number, plus one extra dot.



    1. How many dots will be in Step 5 in the pattern, and how will they be arranged?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

In Step 5, there will be 2 rows of 5 dots plus one additional dot.



  1. Look at Pattern 2.
    1. How is the number of dots in each step changing?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Each step has as many rows and columns of dots as the step number.



    1. How many dots will be in Step 5 in the pattern, and how will they be arranged?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Step 5 is a 5-by-5 array of dots.


Consider the following table.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 4 has 9 dots in Pattern 1.

The correct answer is 9. Step 4 has 9 dots in Pattern 1.

    1. In Step 5, what is the number of dots in Pattern 1?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 5 has 11 dots in Pattern 1.

The correct answer is 11. Step 5 has 11 dots in Pattern 1.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 10 has 21 dots in Pattern 1.

The correct answer is 21. Step 10 has 21 dots in Pattern 1.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 12 has 25 dots in Pattern 1.

The correct answer is 25. Step 12 has 25 dots in Pattern 1.


    1. In Step \(n\), what is the number of dots in Pattern 1?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2n+1\)


  1. Complete the table with the number of dots for Pattern 2.
    1. In Step 4, what is the number of dots in Pattern 2?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 4 has 16 dots in Pattern 2.

The correct answer is 16. Step 4 has 16 dots in Pattern 2.

    1. In Step 5, what is the number of dots in Pattern 2?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 5 has 25 dots in Pattern 2.

The correct answer is 25. Step 5 has 25 dots in Pattern 2.

    1. In Step 10, what is the number of dots in Pattern 2?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 10 has 100 dots in Pattern 2.

The correct answer is 100. Step 10 has 100 dots in Pattern 2.

    1. In Step 12, what is the number of dots in Pattern 2?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 12 has 144 dots in Pattern 2.

The correct answer is 144. Step 12 has 144 dots in Pattern 2.


    1. In Step \(n\), what is the number of dots in Pattern 2?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(n \cdot n\) or \(n^2\)




  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Plot the number of dots at each step number for Pattern 1 and Pattern 2.

    1. Pattern 1

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:



    1. Pattern 2

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:



  1. Explain why the graphs of the two patterns look the way they do.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The points representing the first pattern lie on a line because getting from one step to the next involves adding the same number of dots (2 dots). The points representing the second pattern do not lie on a line. They “curve” upward because the number of dots added at each step increases from step to step.

page.title: 7.2.2: Self Check
page.contents: How many squares will be in Step 5?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the number of squares in Step 4. The answer is 30.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of rows is the same as the number of the step, and the number of columns is 1 more than the number of the step. The answer is 30.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The number of rows is the same as the number of the step, and the number of columns is 1 more than the number of the step. Step 5 has 5 rows and 6 columns.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of rows is the same as the number of the step, and the number of columns is 1 more than the number of the step. The answer is 30.

page.title: 7.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Expressions for Patterns

Example 1

Find the number of squares in Step 5:

First, look to see the pattern. Every step, another row and another column are added, plus the two extra squares.

  • Step 1: 1 row of \(3 + 2\)
  • Step 2: 2 rows of \(4 +2\)
  • Step 3: 3 rows of \(5 + 2\)

So the width is always 1 by \(n\), or \(n\). The length is \(n+2\), and then another 2 is added.

Then, draw pictures or create a table:

Step

# of squares

1

5

2

10

3

17

4

26

5

37

At Step 5, there are 37 squares.

Example 2

Find the expression for Step \(n\).

Multiply the length and width, and then add the 2 extra squares:

\(n(n+2)+2 = n^2+2n+n\)

Try It: Writing Expressions for Patterns


Use the figure below to find the number of squares in Step 5 and then Step \(n\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the number of squares in each step:

Notice that each figure adds a row and column, and then subtracts one square. The number of rows is always 2 more than the step number.

Begin by making a table:

Step

# of squares

1

8

2

15

3

24

4

35

5

48

There are 48 squares in Step 5.

Step \(n\) would be found with \((n+2)(n+2)-1\) or \((n+2)^2-1\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.2.3: Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

Here is a pattern of squares.


  1. Is the number of small squares growing linearly? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, there are 3 squares in the first step, 6 squares in the second step, and 11 squares in the third step. So the number of additional squares is 3 going from the first to the second step and 5 going from the second to the third step.


  1. Answer questions a–e to complete the table.

Step

Number of small squares

1

3

2

6

3

11

4

 a. _____

5

 b. _____

10

 c. _____

12

 d. _____

\(n\)

 e. _____

    1. In Step 4, what is the number of small squares?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! Step 4 has 18 small squares.

The correct answer is 18. Step 4 has 18 small squares.

    1. In Step 5, what is the number of small squares?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 5 has 27 small squares.

The correct answer is 27. Step 5 has 27 small squares.

    1. In Step 10, what is the number of small squares?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 10 has 102 small squares.

The correct answer is 102. Step 10 has 102 small squares.

    1. In Step 12, what is the number of small squares?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 12 has 146 small squares.

The correct answer is 146. Step 12 has 146 small squares.


    1. In Step \(n\), what is the number of small squares?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(n^2+2\)



  1. Is the number of small squares growing exponentially? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, from Step 1 to Step 2, the number of squares doubles. From Step 2 to Step 3, the number of squares increases by a factor of \(\frac{11}{6}\). From Step 3 to Step 4, the number of squares increases by a factor of \(\frac{18}{11}\). These growth factors are all different; in contrast, for an exponential function, the values increase by equal growth factors over equal intervals.


The nth expression, \(n^2+2\), is an example of a quadratic expression. A quadratic expression can be written using a squared term. It can be written in other ways as well, but the expression should be able to be written with the highest exponent on the variable as 2.

  • A quadratic relationship is not like a linear relationship because as one quantity increases by a certain amount, the second quantity doesn’t increase by the same amount.
  • A quadratic relationship is not like an exponential relationship because as one quantity increases by a certain amount, the second quantity doesn’t change by the same factor. (In this case, if the number of squares grew exponentially, this would mean that, from each step to the next, the number of squares is multiplied by the same factor.)

Extending Your Thinking

Han wrote \(n(n+2)-2(n-1)\) for the number of small squares in the design at Step \(n\) in the pattern at the beginning of the activity.

  1. Explain why Han is correct.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

At Step \(n\), there is an \(n\) by \(n+2\) rectangle containing \(n(n+2)\) small squares with two columns of \(n-1\) squares removed from either side.


  1. On your own, draw and label what Step 3 would look like when Han was writing his expression.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

I drew a rectangle with three small squares down and five small squares across. Then I removed the two small squares from the first column and the last column.


Video: Quadratic Expressions

Watch the following video to learn more about quadratic expressions.

page.title: 7.2.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is an example of a quadratic expression?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a linear expression. The answer is \(n^2+3\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Since the variable is squared, this is a quadratic expression. The highest exponent is 2, making it quadratic.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is an exponential expression. The answer is \(n^2+3\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a linear expression. The answer is \(n^2+3\).

page.title: 7.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Expression from Patterns

Find the number of dots in Step 5, and write an expression to find \(n\) number of dots.

Step 1
Make a table to help you find the pattern.

Step number

Number of dots

0

4

1

7

2

10

3

13

Step 2
Notice that the start has 2 rows and 2 columns, or 4 dots.
Each step adds a row of 2 dots, plus 1 more dot.
So, each step adds 3 dots.

Step 3
Continuing this linear pattern, Step 5 would have 19 dots.

Step 4
An expression could be \(3n+4\).
This is a linear expression.

Try It: Writing Expression from Patterns


Find the number of dots in Step 5, and write an expression to find \(n\) number of dots.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write an expression from a pattern:

Step

Number of dots

0

1

1

3

2

9

3

19

Each step has that number of dots squared, then doubled, and then one is added.

So, Step 5 would have 51 dots.

The expression would be \(2n^2+1\), where \(n\) is the step number.

This is a quadratic expression.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.2.4: Quadratic Relationships
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here are three patterns of dots.

Pattern A

Pattern B

Pattern C


Which pattern shows a quadratic relationship between the step number and the number of dots? Explain or show how you know.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Pattern B shows a quadratic relationship. 

  • The number of dots is the step number squared plus 1, or \(n^2+1\).
  • Pattern A is growing linearly. It is growing by 2 each time. Pattern C is growing by a factor of 3 each time, so it is growing exponentially.
  • Pattern B is growing by 1, then by 3, and then by 5, which is the pattern we saw in other examples of quadratic relationships in the lesson.

page.title: 7.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here are two patterns of dots.

Pattern A

Pattern B

    1. How many dots will there be in Step 4 of Pattern A?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There will be 4 rows and 4 columns in Step 4.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 16. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many dots will there be in Step 4 of Pattern B?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The relationship is \(n^2+2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 18. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which pattern shows a quadratic relationship between the step number and the number of dots?

Correct! The relationship is \(n^2+2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.2.3 and 7.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Pattern B. This is because the relationship is \(n^2+2\).You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Each expression represents the total number of dots in a pattern where \(n\) represents the step number.

Select two expressions that represent a quadratic relationship between the step number and the total number of dots. (If you get stuck, consider sketching the first few steps of each pattern as described by the expression.)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.2.3 and 7.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are \(n^2\) and \(n \cdot n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the pattern below to answer the questions.

    1. How many blocks are in Step 4?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The length is always \(n+2\), the width is always \(n+2\), and then \(n\) blocks are subtracted.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2 and 7.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 32. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many blocks are in Step 5?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The length is always \(n+2\), the width is always \(n+2\), and then \(n\) blocks are subtracted.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2 and 7.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 44. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many blocks are in Step \(n\)?

Correct! The length is always \(n+2\), the width is \(n+2\), and then \(n\) blocks are subtracted.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2–7.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((n+2)^2-n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe how a pattern is growing.
  • Tell whether a pattern is growing linearly, exponentially, or quadratically.
  • Explain that an expression with a squared term is called quadratic.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.2.1: Squares in a Geometric Pattern
    • In this activity, you explored how different expressions can represent the same figure and still be equivalent.
  • 7.2.2: Constant and Exponential Change
    • In this activity, you wrote an expression to describe a pattern, and then you graphed the values of the step and the number of dots in each figure. One was linear, while the other was not.
    • 7.2.2: Self Check
    • 7.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.2.3: Quadratic Expressions
    • In this activity, you explored a quadratic relationship, including what makes it quadratic and not linear or exponential.
    • 7.2.3: Self Check
    • 7.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.2.4: Quadratic Relationships
    • In this activity, you examined three patterns and chose which one represents a quadratic relationship.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.2.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
